lines.content: This is a project template for a greenfield Java project. It's named after the Java mascot _Duke_. Given below are instructions on how to use it.
Prerequisites: JDK 17, update Intellij to the most recent version.
1. Open Intellij (if you are not in the welcome screen, click `File` > `Close Project` to close the existing project first)
1. Open the project into Intellij as follows:
1. Select the project directory, and click `OK`.
1. If there are any further prompts, accept the defaults.
1. Configure the project to use **JDK 17** (not other versions) as explained in [here](https://www.jetbrains.com/help/idea/sdk.html#set-up-jdk).
In the same dialog, set the **Project language level** field to the `SDK default` option.

1. After that, locate the `src/main/java/Xenon.java` file, right-click it, and choose `Run Xenon.main()` (if the code editor is showing compile errors, try restarting the IDE). If the setup is correct, you should see something like the below as the output:

**Warning:** Keep the `src\main\java` folder as the root folder for Java files (i.e., don't rename those folders or move Java files to another folder outside of this folder path), as this is the default location some tools (e.g., Gradle) expect to find Java files.

Xenon is a desktop app for managing your tasks, optimized for use via a Command Line Interface (CLI) while still having the benefits of a Graphical User Interface (GUI). If you can type fast, Xenon can get your task management tasks done faster than traditional GUI apps.

1. Ensure you have Java `17` or above installed in your Computer.
**Mac** Users: Ensure you have the precise JDK version prescribed here
2. Download the latest `.jar` file from here.
3. Copy the file to the folder you want to use as the _home folder_ for your Xenon.

4. Open a command terminal `cd` into the folder you put the jar file in, and type `java -jar xenon.jar` to run the application.
Alternative: Double-click the jar file to run the application.
5. A GUI similar to the one above should appear in a few seconds.
* dates should be specified in the following format: `dd/MM/yyyy HH:mm`
* commands are case-sensitive e.g., typing Help instead of `help` will not work.
Shows a message displaying all commands available and their usages.
There are three types of tasks that can be added:
Adds a task Todo task to Xenon.
Adds a task Deadline task to Xenon.
Deletes the specified task from Xenon.
* The task number refers to the task number shown in the displayed task list.
* The task number must be a positive integer.
Edits the specified task in Xenon.
Tip: The task to be edited will be prepopulated into the text field for ease of editing. Make necessary changes and press enter to update task.
Marks the specified task as done in Xenon.
* The task number refers to the task number shown in the displayed task list.
* The task number must be a positive integer.
Marks the specified task as undone in Xenon.
* The task number refers to the task number shown in the displayed task list.
* The task number must be a positive integer.
Finds all tasks containing any of the given keywords.
* Only the task description is searched.
* The keyword can be a phrase (e.g. `assignment report`).

| Add Todo task | `todo `
e.g. `todo return book` |

| Add Event | `event /from /to `
e.g. `event camp /from 28/09/2025 09:30 /to 30/09/2025 09:30` |
* A utility class that tracks the state of command operations, such as
* whether editing is in progress and the index of the last modified command.
* Serves as the entry point for the JavaFX application.
* The Main class serves as the entry point for the chatbot application.
* Represents the operations that can be performed by the chatbot.
* Each operation is associated with a keyword, a usage format, and a description.
FIND("find", "find <phrase>", "Find a task by searching for a phrase"),
MARK("mark", "mark <task number>", "Mark a task as done"),
UNMARK("unmark", "unmark <task number>", "Mark a task as undone"),
HELP("help", "help", "Displays a list of available commands"),
Operation(String keyword, String usage, String description) {

* The input is parsed to determine the appropriate command, which is then executed.
* If an exception occurs during execution, an error message is returned.
* @param input The user's input as a string.
* @return A string containing the response generated by executing the command
*         or an error message if any exception occurs during command execution.

* This variant of the AddCommand constructor is used to create a ToDoTask.

* is used to create an Event.

* @param startDate The start date and time of the Event.

* Tokenizes the given command body string based on a specified delimiter.
* Each token is trimmed of leading and trailing whitespace.
* If the number of tokens is lower than expected, a XenonException is thrown.
* @param commandBody The input string to be tokenised.
* @param splitBy The regex delimiter used to split the input string.
* @param expectedTokens The expected number of tokens to be obtained after splitting.
* @param errorMessage The error message to include in the exception if the token count is lower than expected.
* @return An array of strings containing the tokens after splitting and trimming.
* @throws XenonException If the number of tokens is lower than the expected count.

* The Storage class handles the loading and saving of task data to a file.
* It provides methods to read and write a list of tasks to a specified

* Loads a list of tasks from a file at the specified file path.
* If the file does not exist, a new empty file will be created.
* Each line in the file is interpreted as a task and converted into a Task object.
* Invalid task data will be skipped, and an error message will be printed to the console.

* and date(s) should be provided in ISO format.
